description: From Middle English crouse, from Old English crūse (“jar, cruse”), from Proto-Germanic *krūsǭ, *krūsaz (“jar, pot, collar, jug”). Cognate with German Krause (“pot with a lid”), Icelandic krús (“jar, jug”). Merged with Middle English croo (“pot, pitcher”), from Old English crōg (“crock, pitcher, vessel”). More at crock.

entries.meaning: (religion or obsolete) A small jar used to hold liquid, such as oil or water.
examples: With a thought I tooke for Maudline& a cruse of cockle pottage.with a thing thus tall, skie blesse you all:I befell into this dotage.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) An oil lamp or similar emblem.
